resources.string: You haven\'t tuned any pianos yet.\nCreate new tuning file to start tuning a piano

Adjust the weight ratio for individual inharmonicity measurements vs. the best fit average inharmonicity curve. Decreasing this value will make the tuning curve look smoother, but the tuning targets won\'t align as well with the spacing of harmonics. (Default: 0.75)
Maximum overshoot to avoid breaking strings during pitch raise:
This multiplier can force more or less overshoot during a pitch raise. For example, increasing this to 1.25 would increase the calculated overshoot by 25%. (Default: 1.00)
Select the highest note in the midsection
Select the note with the lowest unwound (plain wire) strings

NOTE: The \"free\" version of this app is primarily for evaluation, and it only allows you to tune notes on the piano between C3 and C5. To tune the entire piano you will need to buy an upgrade through an in-app purchase.
Style implemented as global default and applied to current tuning
You have unsaved changes. Save changes before exit?
Measure pitch of the selected notes, then press \"START PITCH RAISE\"
Select up to 4 notes to measure the current pitch in each octave
An error occurred while performing tuning file backup
You\'re not connected to the Internet
Error loading list of backup files. Please check your internet connection and try again.
Add all tuning files, overwriting duplicates
Cannot load tuning style, reverting to default
This audio sample rate of this device is not sufficient for the frequency range of a piano, or is not supported. Please use a different device.
No internet connection. Please connect to the internet before proceeding
Temperament not found. Tuning file restored with Equal temperament
Error purchasing: %1$s. Please check your internet connection and try again.

The internal clock inside most modern devices is accurate enough calibration should not be necessary, however you can calibrate the device to an external reference by accessing the calibration page from the main menu. To calibrate, first enter the calibration source frequency in the box, then while playing the calibration tone, toggle the calibration offset until the spinner stops. This calibration will then be saved until the app is uninstalled from your device.\n\nNote that because PianoMeter uses multi-partial tuning and expects tones with significant inharmonicity, testing the calibration outside of the calibration page will not work if the reference tone has any harmonics other than the fundamental 440 Hz frequency.

Quick start steps for tuning a piano:

1. Create a new tuning file (Menu ➔ New tuning file) or load a saved file (pro version only).

2. Sample inharmonicity to create a tuning curve. Play several notes across the range of the piano, playing each note for approximately 2 seconds. It is important to sample notes in the mid-section, tenor, and bass. The program is always listening and will automatically calculate an ideal tuning curve based on the inharmonicity of the sampled notes. Note: if the unisons are significantly out of tune you will get better and faster results by using mutes to isolate single strings.

3. Rough tuning (optional): If the piano is more than about 10 cents sharp or flat you should do a rough tuning (“pitch adjustment” or “pitch raise”). Even if the piano is within ±3 cents of standard pitch it is still advisable to run through the notes quickly and fix any outliers, as this will result in a better fine tuning. The benefit of doing this pre-tuning pass is that the app will gather more inharmonicity data and further refine the tuning curve. If you skip this step you might consider quickly sampling inharmonicity for all the notes on the piano (except the treble) which takes less than 2 minutes.

4. Lock the tuning curve using the “ear” button on the right. This stops further inharmonicity measurement and prevents the tuning curve from changing during a fine tuning.

5. Tune the piano. The recommended order is to tune the midsection first, starting at the tenor break (often around D#3), tune up through the treble, and then tune the bass last.

There are 3 possible displays in the graphing area that can be accessed by swiping left or right or tapping on the left or right sides of the graph.

The primary graph plots the tuning curve or "Railsback curve" that shows the degree to which the tuning is stretched from pure octave equal temperament (which would be a flat horizontal line through the middle of the graph). However inharmonicity requires that we "stretch" the tuning of octaves slightly, resulting in the lower registers of the piano being tuned slightly flat and the upper registers being tuned slightly sharp. Whenever a note is played its pitch is plotted on the graph as a dot, allowing the user to see at a glance to see what the entire tuning looks like. For a perfectly in-tune piano, the dots will all fall exactly on tuning curve line. The vertical scale on the tuning curve graph goes from −50 to +50 cents.

The left graph shows the frequency spectrum from about 27 Hz (near the fundamental frequency of A0) to about 4300 Hz (near the frequency of C8). The frequencies are plotted on a logarithmic scale so that peaks in the spectrum align with their respective notes on the piano keyboard below. You will notice that most notes on the piano excite multiple peaks on the spectrum. These peaks correspond to the individual harmonics that make up each tone.

The right graph plots the measured inharmonicity of each note on the piano on a logarithmic scale. Inharmonicity is the degree to which the harmonics of a note are "out of tune" with the fundamental (lowest harmonic). The inharmonicity is a function of the length and stiffness of piano strings. Shorter and thicker strings have high inharmonicity, while longer or thinner strings have low inharmonicity. The inharmonicity affects the tuning of pianos, and each piano will be tuned differently because pianos are designed with different lengths of strings and sizes of wire. Also on the graph is a "best fit" line that is used to interpolate for notes that have not been measured yet, and to extrapolate to the top octave where inharmonicity is not measured.

By default, whenever the app is running it will be listening for and measuring the inharmonicity of each note. As new information is acquired it repeatedly recalculates the tuning in order to give the best tuning based on all available data. Generally the changes in tuning are quite small after the initial inharmonicity measurements of several notes across the range of the piano. However, it may be desirable to at some point “lock” a tuning to protect it from any future changes. This is achieved by toggling the button on the right side of the screen from “Listen” mode to “Lock” mode. A good time to do this might be after a pitch adjustment, when the inharmonicity of most notes has been measured.

There are 3 note switching modes available through a selector on the main screen.

Automatic note switching allows the app to detect and jump to any note played on the keyboard.

Stepwise note switching allows the note to step up and down a scale, but prevents longer range jumps. While tuning chromatically this mode will prevent octave jumps that sometimes occur during long sustains, or random jumps due to background noise.

Lock mode will prevent all automatic switching, locking to the current note.

In all three modes you can always switch the note by half steps or octaves by tapping arrow buttons to the right and left of the center note display.

A Pitch Raise (pro version only) is a rough pre-tuning for pianos that are very out of tune and need to be tuned in two passes. In a pitch raise you tune the piano slightly above pitch (overshoot) so when the large increase in string tension makes the piano go flat again it will be roughly in tune. To begin a pitch raise, open the Pitch Raise dialogue from the main menu, then select the type of piano you are tuning. (The overshoot profile is slightly different on grand pianos vs. uprights.)

Next select the lowest unwound (plain wire) strings, and the highest string in the mid-section.

Finally select up to 4 notes per octave to pre-measure for calculating the pitch raise overshoot. These notes must be at least a minor third (3 half-steps) apart to avoid measuring the wrong note in pianos that are more than 100 cents flat. Two notes per octave (for example A’s and D#s) is sufficient. Press “Continue” and then play each note for every octave on the piano until the corresponding dot in the graphing area stabilizes. It is not necessary to measure all notes in every octave. PianoMeter will interpolate and extrapolate.

When you are satisfied that the initial pitch for each note is measured accurately, press the “Start Pitch Raise” button. The graphing area at the bottom will now show a black line representing the tuning curve and a green line representing the target overshoot. The dial at the top will also rotate for each note to indicate the overshoot, and the pitch targets for the strobe rings will be adjusted. When a note is in tune the strobe rings will stop and the needle will be pointing directly up (which will generally not be zero). For the tuning order, it is recommended to start tuning at the tenor break (bottom of the mid-section) and tune upward to the top of the piano, then tune the bass strings last, working downward from the tenor break. For example, if the lowest note in the mid-section is D#3, first tune from D#3 to C8, then from D3 to A0. Finally press “Exit Pitch Raise” and fine-tune the piano in a second pass.

In the pro version it is possible to save tuning files that store the inharmonicity and tuning curve for pianos. The tuning files can then be loaded at a later date to re-tune the same piano.

Although tuning files are saved automatically, you can input a name and/or identifying information for each file. This is done via Menu ➔ Tuning file settings. There you can enter information about the manufacturer, model, serial number, type of piano, and the name of the piano’s owner (for professional tuners with multiple clients) and other miscellaneous information about the piano. This information is for piano identification only and does not affect the tuning curve.

To load a previously saved tuning file, go to Menu ➔ Load tuning file, and then simply select the tuning file you wish to load. Saved tuning files can be sorted by name, manufacturer, and date accessed; you can also locate tuning files using the search bar at the top of the screen.

Long-pressing a tuning file brings up a special menu with options to copy, rename, delete, or "share" a tuning file (exporting it to email, messaging, dropbox, etc.)

There are multiple ways to see whether a note is sharp or flat. The text in the center of the screen displays the note being played and how many “cents” sharp or flat it is. Surrounding the center circle are a series of spinning bars, similar to a stroboscopic tuner’s phase display, whose direction and speed indicate how out of tune a note is. Clockwise spinning means the note is sharp, while counter-clockwise indicates the note is flat. Each set of spinning bars represents a specific harmonic of the note being played, and small numbers in the lower right indicate which harmonics are being measured. If a harmonic is not present in the tone, the corresponding spinner will not be displayed. Finally there is a pointer with a non-linear scale that indicates how sharp or flat the note is, again in cents. (A cent equals a hundredth of a half step.)

By default tunings will be calculated around the international A=440 Hz pitch standard. If you wish to tune to a frequency other than A=440, this is possible via the Tuning file settings page, where you can set an alternate frequency standard (eg. A=415 or A=442) or an offset in cents from A=440. Changing this only affects the current tuning. If you wish to set an alternate default pitch standard for tuning files, this can be done on the Calibration page.

The tuning style can be customized by adjusting “weights” that are assigned to various slow-beating intervals. Intervals with higher weight will be tuned more pure than intervals with lower weight, but all intervals will be tempered slightly in the tuning calculation.

 • Octaves can be used to somewhat control the “stretch” of a tuning. A high 2:1 octave weight reduces the stretch overall, and the 10:5 octave weight greatly affects the stretch of the low bass.

 Pure 12ths (5th plus an octave) generally result in a balanced tuning, so by default the 12ths are given a high weight.

 5ths and 4ths are tuned narrow and wide respectively, so adjusting their weights can somewhat alter the overall stretch.

 Double octaves tend to be important for the high treble.

 Triple octaves and 19ths help ensure the piano sounds consonant when large chords are played. Triple octaves affect the stretch throughout the piano, especially in the treble and bass.

 You can also manually add or subtract extra stretch in the treble or bass for a specified number of notes/octaves.

The graph shows a tuning curve in black, and the width of different octave types in blue for the calculated tuning. A positive value indicates that the interval is tuned wide of pure, and a negative value indicates an interval tuned narrow of pure. For example, the line for the 2:1 octave has a value of approximately +2.0 at “A4”. This means that the 2:1 A4-A5 octave is tuned approximately 2 cents (0.5 beats per second) wide. (The 4:2 A4-A5 octave is tuned very nearly pure.) The varying darkness of the blue lines are a rough indicator of the strength of that interval throughout the range of the piano. For example, the 2:1 octave is strong through the midsection of the piano and into the treble, but is weak in the bass because the fundamental (1st) and 2nd harmonics are absent in the tone of the lowest bass notes. By contrast, the 8:4 and 10:5 octaves are strongest in the tenor and bass regions. The strength of each interval also affects the weight it is given in the final calculation of the tuning curve.
Tuning to frequencies other than A=440
This app needs to record audio through the microphone
Please grant the Microphone permission in the app\'s permissions, then restart the app.
This app needs to access external storage for tuning file import/export
Please open your device settings and grant permission for this app to access storage, then restart the app.
This will be applied to future new tuning files.
Tuning functionality for select sample notes only, mostly in the mid-range of the piano. Evaluate if a piano is roughly in tune using the graph at the bottom
Calibrate device to an external frequency source
Tune to frequency standards other than A=440
Tuning functionality for the entire piano (not just the mid-range)
Choose from a selection of historical temperaments or create your own
Pitch raise functionality that calculates overshoot for a \'rough\' tuning (for pianos that are extremely flat)
Save and load multiple tuning files so a piano doesn\'t need to be re-measured each time it is tuned
Create custom tuning curves by adjusting interval weighting and stretch
Not enough note data for pitch raise!
Tone generator is now active. Because the microphone is still on, please use headphones with the volume at a safe level and lock the tuning curve.

The tone generator has two modes:

· Timed mode plays a tone for a set duration each time you time you switch notes. Long-press on the stopwatch button to adjust the time.

· Continuous mode will play each tone constantly until you change notes but won't repeat tones if you later return to recently tuned notes. Consider using this mode for non-linear tuning sequences like tuning the middle string of a new note before the outer strings of the previous note (for instance tuning with a strip mute or leapfrogging two mutes).

Use these settings to fine-tune the volume for the treble and bass and compensate for frequency response differences between headphones. The up-and-down sliders adjust the volume level; the horizontal sliders adjust the range of notes affected by the volume sliders.
